Award.AwardTitle: A CEREUS (Consortium Exchanging Research Experiences for Undergraduate Students) Approach to Assessing Ecological Responses in the Southern Appalachians to Environmental Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Phenology, the study of seasonal biological events, tracks the effects of both year to year climate variability and long-term environmental change on both local and global ecology. It has considerable potential for serving as a base for research studies by undergraduate classes and developing cross-campus studies. Several recent studies, including the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (2014), and Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education (a 2011 document representing the views of over 500 biology faculty and administrators) cite the importance of undergraduate research for retaining science majors and helping students better understand key concepts and develop crucial competencies. Four institutions, the University of North Carolina at Asheville, Appalachian State University, East Tennessee State University, and Warren Wilson College, are combining forces to create common gardens and to develop modules that can guide students' research studies to address potential impacts of global change at multiple levels of the biological hierarchy, from genes to ecosystems. The cooperating institutions are unique in character, diverse in their student bodies, and located in varying climate zones. The project will contribute to our knowledge about ecological issues and will expand the ways in which institutions can combine forces to increase the STEM knowledge and competencies of their students. Environmental change issues to be investigated include monitoring effects of invasive exotic removal techniques on herbs, shrubs, vines, and trees within the areas studied (studies for lower division courses), and exploring questions about the spread of potentially invasive exotic plants, using a combination of GIS (Global Information Systems) mapping, herbarium collections, and online databases (upper division courses).

The collaborating institutions will create and beta-test modules, identify and mitigate barriers to successful implementation of curricular changes, and disseminate curricular changes. The modules will have a direct impact on the learning of over 2000 undergraduates per year, including non-STEM majors. They will be developed and partially administered by undergraduate and graduate research students, and will be instrumental in developing pedagogical expertise for faculty members. The ability of modules to impart botanical knowledge while encouraging higher-order cognitive processes, advancing quantitative literacy, teaching analytical techniques, honing scientific communication skills, cultivating positive student attitudes towards plants and STEM, and improving persistence and graduation in STEM majors will be assessed using a mixed method approach (quantitative and qualitative data collection). Results will begin to document the effects of global change on an understudied but important bioregion while developing a future workforce with solid STEM training.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education, in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Consortium Exchanging Research Experiences for Undergraduate Students (CEREUS) project engages undergraduate students in research projects focused on assessing ecological responses to global change in Southern Appalachia. The consortium is comprised of faculty from four different undergraduate institutions in Southern Appalachia: UNC-Asheville, Appalachian State University, Warren Wilson College, and East Tennessee State University. Faculty at each institution are involved in projects that incorporate plant-based authentic research experiences embedded within courses and many students are also engaged in independent research on projects with CEREUS faculty.

Since the CEREUS project began faculty within the consortium have met both digitally and physically several times per year to discuss, revise, and develop new research-based modules that aim to equip our undergraduates with the 21st Century skills necessary for tomorrow's STEM workforce. Throughout the project we have collected student data to assess the instructional effectiveness of these modules and how these modules impact both affective and cognitive domains of student learning. Students who participate in CEREUS modules are more likely to have an increased awareness of the value of plants around them and have improved self-efficacy with respect to their identity as a scientist. CEREUS PI's have presented data on student outcomes and shared resources at the National Association of Biology Teachers conference in 2016, the Ecological Society of America Conference in 2017, and at the Association of Southeastern Biologists in 2018. Additionally, undergraduate students participating in CEREUS research activities have presented at the Future of Ginseng and Forest Botanicals Symposium in 2017, the 2018 UNC System-Wide Undergraduate Research Development Summit and the 2018 Association of Southeastern Biologists Meeting. Several of the CEREUS PI's also held a workshop for faculty on undergraduate research experiences at the Association of Southeastern Biologists Meeting with twenty participants from a diversity of institutions in the southeastern united states. 

The impact of the project on each institution has been tremendous; namely, an increasing number of students are interested in pursing the plant sciences and whole departments of faculty have significantly shifted their priorities in improving student science practice skills through research experiences. The project has also had a significant impact on the infrastructure at each institution to sustain and support plant-based research projects for future student populations. Some institutions have been able to secure matching funds from their administration to further expand and support both undergraduate research experiences and public STEM outreach efforts. 

Three years worth of student data and continual plant-based research data collection will provide the PI's with ample evidence to produce curricular materials and peer-reviewed research articles in science and science education. Two manuscripts are in preparation for publication in science education research journals. PI's plan to continue to share resources, to present student outcomes data, and to present plant science research findings at professional society meetings and PI's plan to continue to support undergraduate research presentations at regional and national meetings.
